__data__.text: Optics is a branch of physics that studies the behavior and characteristics of light.
Light is electromagnetic radiation with a wavelength between 380 nm and 750 nm.
Light is perceived by the human eye and is located in the visible spectrum between infrared and ultraviolet radiation.
Light consists of massless elementary particles called photons.
Photons move at a speed of 299 792 458 m/s in a vacuum.
The speed of light in matter depends on its refractive index, which is calculated by the formula n=c/v.
Light makes objects visible to the human eye.
The origin of light can be in celestial bodies, natural phenomena, or materials in combustion, ignition, or incandescence.
Human beings have devised different procedures to obtain light in spaces lacking it, such as torches, candles, candlesticks, lamps, or electric lighting.
Light is both the agent that enables vision and a visible phenomenon in itself.
Light enables the perception of color.
Color reaches the retina through light rays that are transmitted by the retina to the optic nerve.
The optic nerve transmits nerve impulses to the brain.
The perception of light is a psychological process.
Physical objects have different levels of luminance or reflectance.
Luminance affects the color of objects, from white (maximum reflection) to black (maximum absorption).
Black and white are not considered colors of the conventional chromatic circle.
Black and white are gradations of brightness and darkness.
Shadows are transitions of brightness and darkness.
When white light hits a surface of a certain color, photons of that color are reflected.
Reflected photons illuminate another surface with the same color, an effect known as radiance.
If an object is the same color, it reinforces its level of colored luminosity, i.e. its saturation.
White light from the sun consists of a continuous spectrum of colors.

The chromatic spectrum includes different shades or tones of colors.
The chromatic circle represents the colors of the chromatic spectrum.
There are three primary colors: lemon yellow, magenta red, and cyan blue.
If primary colors are mixed, secondary colors are obtained: orange red, bluish violet, and green.
If a primary color and a secondary color are mixed, tertiary colors are obtained.
Complementary colors are two colors that are on opposite sides of the chromatic circle.
Adjacent colors are those that are close within the chromatic circle.
If a color is mixed with an adjacent color, it is shaded.
If a color is mixed with a complementary color, it is neutralized or darkened.
Three factors define color: hue, saturation, and value.
Hue is the position within the chromatic circle.
Saturation is the purity of the color.
Value is the level of luminosity of a color.
The main source of light is the sun.
The perception of sunlight varies according to the time of day.
Mid-morning or mid-afternoon light is generally blue, clear, and diaphanous.
Midday light is whiter and more intense, with high contrast and darker shadows.
Dusk light is more yellowish, soft, and warm.
Sunset light is orange or red, low contrast, with intense bluish shadows.
Evening light is a darker red, dimmer light, with weaker shadows and contrast.
The light of cloudy skies depends on the time of day and the degree of cloudiness.
Night light can be lunar or some atmospheric refraction of sunlight.
Natural light that filters indoors is a diffuse light of lower intensity.
"North light" is the light that enters through a north-facing window.
Artificial light sources include fire, candles, electric, fluorescent, and photographic.

High key lighting is a term used when white or light tones predominate in an image.
Low key lighting is a term used when black or dark tones predominate in an image.
Shadows can be of two types: shape (also called "self shadows") and projection ("cast shadows").
Self shadows are the shaded areas of a physical object and define the volume and texture of the object.
Cast shadows are the shadows cast by objects on some surface, usually the ground, and help define space.
The lightest part of the shadow is the "umbra" and the darkest part is the "penumbra".
The shape and appearance of the shadow depend on the size and distance of the light source.
Shadows from small or distant sources have sharp edges and a large penumbra.
Shadows from large or close sources have more diffuse edges and a larger umbra.
A shadow can receive illumination from a secondary source, known as "fill light".
The color of a shadow is between blue and black and depends on several factors, such as light contrast, transparency and translucency.
The projection of shadows is different for natural and artificial light.
With natural light, the beams are parallel and the shadow adapts both to the terrain and to the various obstacles that may intervene.
With artificial light, the beams are divergent, with less defined limits, and if there are several light sources, combined shadows may be produced.
The reflection of light produces four derived phenomena: glints, glares, color reflections, and image reflections.
Glints are reflections of the light source, be it the sun, artificial lights or incidental sources such as doors and windows.
Glares are reflections produced by illuminated bodies as a reflective screen, especially white surfaces.
Color reflections are produced by the proximity between various objects, especially if they are luminous.
Image reflections are produced by polished surfaces, such as mirrors or water.
Transparency occurs in bodies that are not opaque, with a greater or lesser degree depending on the opacity of the object.
Light can be intrinsic or extrinsic in origin.
Intrinsic light is homogeneous and without luminous effects, and it was mainly used in Romanesque and Gothic art.
Extrinsic light presents contrasts, directional lights, and objective sources of light, and it was commonly used in the Renaissance and Baroque.
Extrinsic light can occur in different ways, including focal light, diffuse light, real light, and unreal light.
Focal light directly presents a light-emitting object or comes from an external source that illuminates the painting.
Diffuse light blurs the contours, as seen in Leonardo's sfumato.
Real light aims to realistically capture sunlight, and artists like Claude of Lorraine, J.M.W. Turner, and the impressionists employed this technique.
Unreal light has no natural or scientific basis and is closer to a symbolic light, as in the illumination of religious figures.
Light can be compositional or conceptual in terms of the artist's intention.
Compositional light helps the composition of the painting, while conceptual light enhances the message by illuminating a certain part of the painting and leaving the rest in semi-darkness.
In relation to its origin, light can be natural ambient light or projected light.
Natural ambient light has no shadows of figures or objects, while projected light generates shadows and serves to model the figures.
The source of light in a painting is the element that radiates the light, be it the sun, a candle, or any other.
The focus of light is the part of the painting that has the most luminosity and radiates it around the painting.
The interrelation between light and shadow is called chiaroscuro.
If the dark area is larger than the illuminated one, it is called tenebrism.
The painter determines the illumination of the painting, which marks the composition and expression of the image.
The shadow provides solidity and volume and can generate dramatic effects.

The light source can be present in a painting or not.
The light source can have a direct or indirect origin.
The light source can be internal or external to the painting.
Light defines the space through the modeling of volumes.
Modeling of volumes is achieved with the contrast between light and shadow.
The relationship between the values of light and shadow defines the volumetric characteristics of the form.
The scale of values can range from a soft fade to a hard contrast.
Spatial limits can be objective.
Objective spatial limits are produced by people, objects, architectures, natural elements and other factors of corporeality.
Spatial limits can be subjective.
Subjective spatial limits come from sensations such as atmosphere, depth, a hollow, an abyss, etc.
In human perception, light creates closeness and darkness creates remoteness.
A light-darkness gradient gives a sensation of depth.
Aspects such as contrast, relief, texture, volume, gradients or the tactile quality of the image depend on light.
The play of light and shadow helps to define the location and orientation of objects in space.
For the correct representation of objects in space, their shape, density and extension, as well as their differences in intensity must be taken into account.
Apart from its physical qualities, light can generate dramatic effects.
Light can give the painting a certain emotional atmosphere.
Contrast is a fundamental factor in painting.
Contrast is the language with which the image is shaped.
There are two types of contrast: luminous and chromatic.
Luminous contrast can be by chiaroscuro (light and shadow) or by surface (a point of light that shines brighter than the rest).
Chromatic contrast can be tonal (contrast between two tones) or by saturation (a bright color with a neutral one).
Both types of contrast are not mutually exclusive.
Contrast can have different levels of intensity.

Warm colors include red, orange, purple, yellowish green, and black.
Cool colors include blue, green, and violet, as well as white.
The perception of color with respect to its temperature is subjective and comes from Goethe's Theory of Colors.
Harmonizing between complementary colors produces the greatest chromatic contrast.
Broken ranges consist of neutralization by mixing primary colors and their complementary colors.
This produces intense luminous effects.
The chromatic vibration is more subtle in broken ranges.
Saturated colors stand out more in broken ranges.
The quality and appearance of the luminous representation is linked to the technique used.
In drawing, whether in pencil or charcoal, the effects of light are achieved through the black-white duality.
White is generally the color of the paper in drawing.
Pencil is usually worked with line and hatching.
Blurred spots can be used in pencil drawing.
Charcoal allows the use of gouache and chalk or white chalk to add touches of light.
Sanguine or sepia can also be used with charcoal.
Indian ink generates violent chiaroscuro.
Indian ink does not have intermediate values.
Indian ink is a very expressive medium.
Oil painting consists of dissolving the colors in an oily binder.
Turpentine is added to oil painting to make it dry better.
Oil painting allows for the best valuation of light effects and chromatic tones.
Oil painting produces vivid colors and intense effects of brightness and brilliance.
Oil painting allows a free and fresh stroke.
Oil painting allows a great richness of textures.
Brushes, spatulas, or scrapers can be used in oil painting.
Multiple textures can be produced in oil painting.
Thin layers and glazes can be produced in oil painting.
Thick fillings can be produced in oil painting.
Pastel painting is made with a pigment pencil
Interiors generally have a type of indirect light that is filtered through doors or windows, or filtered by curtains or other elements.
Private scenes are usually developed in interiors, which are reinforced by contrasts of light and shadow.
The artist can manipulate the light at will in still life paintings, which usually show a series of objects or food arranged as in a sideboard.
The main difficulty in still life paintings is the correct evaluation of the tones and textures of the objects, as well as their brightness and transparency depending on the material.
Exteriors are enveloped in a luminous atmosphere determined by the time of day and the weather and environmental conditions.
The main challenge for the artist in landscape, seascape, and skyscape paintings is to capture the precise tone of the natural light according to various conditions and variables.
Artists have gone out to paint in nature to capture their impressions first hand, a working method known as "en plein air".
Artificial illumination of the cities and the presence of neon lights and other types of effects are factors to take into account in urban landscape paintings.
Light affects the volume of the human figure and generates different limits according to the play of light and shadow.
The focus of the light is important, since its direction influences the general contour of the figure and the illumination of its surroundings.
Direct light or shadow on the skin modifies the color, varying the tonality from the characteristic pale pink to gray or white.
The light can also be filtered by objects that get in its path, which generates different effects and colors on the skin.
In the portrait genre, light plays a decisive role in the modeling of the face.
The portrait genre is characterized by a greater demand in the faithful representation of the physiognomic features and even the need to capture the psychology of the character.
In the 20th century, abstraction emerged as a new pictorial language, in which painting is reduced to non-figurative images that no longer describe reality.
In abstract paintings, artists play with form, color, light, matter, space and other elements in a totally subjective way and not subject to conventionalisms.
The drawing of portraits requires a faithful representation of the physiognomic features and the psychology of the character.
The drawing is essential to model the features of the portrait according to the model.
In the 20th century, abstraction emerged as a new pictorial language.
In abstract painting, painting is reduced to non-figurative images that no longer describe reality.
In abstract painting, artists play with form, color, light, matter, space and other elements in a subjective way.
In abstract painting, light is still present on numerous occasions.
Until the Renaissance, artists did not represent a specific time in painting.
In general, the only difference in light was between exterior and interior lights.
Night was rarely represented until practically Mannerism.
In many occasions, it is difficult to identify the specific time of day in a work.
In Giotto's The Annunciation to the Shepherds and in Ambrogio Lorenzetti's Annunciation, the nocturnal atmosphere contributes to accentuate the halo of mystery surrounding the birth of Christ.
In Uccello's Saint George and the Dragon, night represents evil.
In narrative themes that take place at night, this factor is sometimes deliberately avoided.
Practically until the 19th century, the chronological setting of a scene has been linked to its narrative correlate.
In the past, time was more of a narrative factor, accompanying the action represented.
The temporal dimension began to gain relevance in the 17th century.
In the 17th century, artists such as Claude Lorrain and Salvator Rosa began to detach landscape painting from a narrative context.
The first light of the day is that of dawn, sunrise or aurora.
Until the 17th century, dawn appeared only in small pieces of landscape.
The light of dawn generally has a spherical effect.

Dawn appeared only in small pieces of the landscape until the 17th century.
The light of dawn has a spherical effect.
Leonardo's aerial perspective was not widely used until the appearance of his technique.
Francesco Milizia wrote about the effects of dawn in his Dictionary of the Fine Arts of Design in 1797.
Milizia states that dawn sweetly colors the extremity of bodies and begins to dissipate the darkness of the night.
The air is still full of vapors at dawn, leaving objects appearing wavering.
The shadows cannot be very sensitive at dawn because the sun has not yet appeared.
All bodies must participate in the freshness of the air and remain in a kind of half-ink at dawn.
The background of the sky wants to be dark blue at dawn so that the celestial vault stands out better.
The sky will be colored of a reddish-red incarnation from a certain height with alternating golden and silver bands at dawn.
The light of dawn was the most suitable for the representation of landscapes according to Milizia.
Noon and the hours immediately before and after have always been a stable frame for an objective representation of reality.
It is difficult to pinpoint the exact moment in most paintings due to different light intensities.
The exact noon was discouraged by its extreme refulgence.
Leonardo advised keeping the window covered in such a way that the sun does not change the situation if painting at noon.
Milizia states that it is not possible to imitate the brightness of midday that dazzles the eye.
The sun should be hidden among clouds, trees, mountains and buildings if painting at noon.
The bodies do not give shadows, or little, and the colors appear less vivid at noon.
Most art treatises advised the afternoon light, which was the most used especially from the Renaissance to the 18th century.
Vasari advised placing the sun to the east because "the figure that is made has a great relief and great goodness and perfection is achieved".

Renaissance artists found it challenging to work in a nocturnal setting.
Lorenzo Ghiberti stated that it is not possible to see anything in darkness.
Leonardo wrote that darkness means complete deprivation of light.
Leonardo advised that a night scene should be illuminated by a fire as an artifice to make it diurnal.
Leonardo's sfumato opened a door to a naturalistic representation of the night.
The chromatic decrease in the distance in Leonardo's luminous air can become a bluish black for the night.
The first creates an effect of remoteness, while the second provokes closeness.
Baroque tenebrism uses darkness to add drama to the scene and to emphasize certain parts of the painting.
In the 17th century, the representation of the night acquired a more scientific character.
The invention of the telescope by Galileo led to a more detailed observation of the night sky.
Advances in artificial lighting in the 19th century boosted the conquest of nighttime.
Impressionists captured the nighttime as a time for leisure and entertainment.
A painter's job is to distinguish the light of each day of the week.
Light has had a symbolic meaning, especially related to religion.
Light has been associated with beauty, knowledge, good, happiness, and life.
Shadows and darkness represent evil, death, ignorance, immorality, misfortune, or secrecy.
Many religions and philosophies are based on the dichotomy between light and darkness.
Light has been associated with the immaterial and spiritual.
The identification of light with a transcendent meaning comes from antiquity.
In many ancient religions, the deity was identified with light.
Primitive peoples had a transcendental concept of light, generally linked to immortality.
Many cultures sketched a place of infinite light where the souls rested.
Many religious rites were based on "illumination" to purify the soul.

In Greek mythology, Apollo was the god of the Sun.
Apollo was often depicted in art within a disk of light.
Apollo was also the god of beauty and the arts.
The concept of light is symbolic of beauty and the arts in Greek mythology.
In Greek mythology, the goddess of dawn is Eos.
In Roman mythology, the goddess of dawn is Aurora.
In Ancient Greece, light was synonymous with life.
The fluctuation of light was related to emotional changes in Ancient Greece.
The fluctuation of light was related to intellectual capacity in Ancient Greece.
In Greek mythology, the shadow had a negative component.
The shadow was related to the dark and hidden in Greek mythology.
In Greek mythology, the shadow was related to evil forces.
The spectral shadows were associated with Tartarus in Greek mythology.
The Greeks related the sun to "intelligent light" (φῶς νοετόν).
"Intelligent light" (φῶς νοετόν) was considered a driving principle of the movement of the universe in Ancient Greece.
Plato drew a parallel between light and knowledge.
In the Bible, the phrase "let there be light" is used.
In the Bible, "God saw that the light was good" is written.
In Hebrew, the term "good" has an ethical sense.

The symbolism of light passing through glass is similar to the concept applied to Gothic stained glass.
In Gothic stained glass, light symbolizes divine omnipresence.
Another symbolism related to light is that which identifies Jesus with the Sun and Mary as the Dawn that precedes him.
In Christianity, light can also signify truth, virtue and salvation.
In patristics, light is a symbol of eternity and the heavenly world.
According to Saint Bernard, souls separated from the body will be "plunged into an immense ocean of eternal light and luminous eternity".
In ancient Christianity, baptism was initially called "illumination".
In Orthodox Christianity, light is, more than a symbol, a "real aspect of divinity".
According to Saint Simeon the New Theologian, God never appears as any image or figure, but shows himself in his simplicity, formed by light without form, incomprehensible, ineffable.
Because of the opposition of light and darkness, light has often been represented in various acts and ceremonies such as circumcision, baptisms, weddings or funerals, in the form of candles or fires.

In Christian iconography, light is present in the halos of the saints, which used to be made —especially in medieval art — with a golden nimbus, a circle of light placed around the heads of saints, angels and members of the Holy Family.
In Fra Angelico's The Annunciation, the artist placed rays of light radiating from the figure of the archangel Gabriel to emphasize his divinity.
In The Baptism of Christ (1445) by Piero della Francesca, God himself is represented in the form of rays of sunlight.
In The Tempest (1505) by Giorgione, rays of light represent God's wrath.
In the vanitas genre, beams of light are used to focus on objects whose transience is to be emphasized as a symbol of the ephemerality of life.

René Descartes spoke of an "inner light" capable of capturing the "eternal truths".
Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz distinguished between lumière naturelle (natural light) and lumière révélée (revealed light).
In the 19th century, German Romantics related light to nature in a pantheistic sense.
For Friedrich Schelling, light was a medium in which the "universal soul" (Weltseele) moved.
For Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel, light was the "ideality of matter", the foundation of the material world.
In the 19th and 20th centuries, a more scientific view of light prevailed.

Two main theories about the nature of light existed: the corpuscular theory, defended by Descartes and Newton; and the wave theory, defended by Christiaan Huygens, Thomas Young and Augustin-Jean Fresnel.
James Clerk Maxwell presented an electromagnetic theory of light.
Albert Einstein brought together the corpuscular and wave theories.
In landscape painting, light can have a symbolic character.
Dawn and the passage from night to day represent the divine plan in general.
Dawn also symbolizes the renewal and redemption of Christ.
The sun and the day are associated with the masculine, the vital force and energy.
The moon and the night are associated with the feminine, rest, sleep and spirituality, sometimes even death.
In Buddhism, light represents truth and the overcoming of matter in the ascent to nirvana.
In Hinduism, light is synonymous with wisdom and the spiritual understanding of participation with divinity (atman).
In Islam, light is the sacred name Nûr.
According to the Koran (24:35), "Allah is the light of the heavens and the earth. Light upon light! Allah guides to his light whomever he wills".
In the Zohar of the Jewish Kabbalah, the primordial light Or (or Awr) appears.

Apollodorus of Athens is credited with the invention of chiaroscuro.
Chiaroscuro is a procedure of contrast between light and shadow in a two-dimensional representation.
The effects of light and shadow were also developed by Greek scenographers in a technique called skiagraphia.
Greek scenographers who used skiagraphia were called "shadow painters".
Aristotle made statements about light and colors in his work.
Aristotle stated that colors are "mixtures of different forces of sunlight and the light of fire, air and water".
Aristotle stated that "darkness is due to the deprivation of light".
Apelles is a famous Greek painter.
Apelles was one of the pioneers in the representation of light in painting.
Pliny the Elder praised Apelles for painting "what cannot be painted, thunder, lightning and thunderbolts".
Nicias of Athens was an outstanding Greek painter.
Pliny the Elder praised Nicias for the "care he took with light and shade to achieve the appearance of relief".
Landscape painting developed a new method for representing distance through gradations of light and shadow.
Early landscape painters created the modeling through shades of light and shadow, without mixing the colors in the palette.
Claudius Ptolemy explained in his Optics how painters created the illusion of depth through distances that seemed "veiled by air".
Strongest contrasts were made in the areas closest to the observer in early landscape painting.
Contrasts progressively reduced towards the background in early landscape painting.
This technique of contrasts in early landscape painting was picked up by early Christian and Byzantine art.
The apsidal mosaic of Sant'Apollinare in Classe is an example of early Christian art that used this technique.
Buddhist murals of Ajantā are an example of this technique in India.
John Philoponus outlined a theory on the subjective effect of light and shadow in painting in the 5th century.
This theory is known today as "Philoponus' rule".
Byzantine art and Romanesque art value the luminosity and splendor of shines and reflections, especially of gold and precious stones.
The shines and reflections in Byzantine and Romanesque art have a more aesthetic than pictorial component.
The shines and reflections in Byzantine and Romanesque art are synonymous with beauty, which is more spiritual than material.
Abbot Suger identified these shines with the divine light to justify his expenditure on jewels and precious materials.
Greek and Roman art laid the foundations of the style known as classicism.
Classicism's main premises are truthfulness, proportion, and harmony.
Classicist painting is based on drawing as a preliminary design tool.
In classicist painting, pigment is applied taking into account a correct proportion of chromaticism and shading.
The classical canons have been returned to in the Renaissance, Baroque classicism, neoclassicism, and academicism.
Medieval art has a strong symbolic component in art, and light is considered a reflection of divinity.
Within medieval scholastic philosophy, a current called the aesthetics of light emerged.
This aesthetics of light identified light with divine beauty and greatly influenced medieval art, especially Gothic art.
Gothic cathedrals are brighter, with large windows that flood the interior space.
The interior space of Gothic cathedrals is indefinite, without limits, as a concretion of an absolute, infinite beauty.
New architectural elements, such as the pointed arch and the ribbed vault, were introduced in Gothic cathedrals.
Buttresses and flying buttresses support the weight of the building in Gothic cathedrals.
Large windows covered with stained glass are used in Gothic cathedrals.
The stained-glass windows in Gothic cathedrals create fantastic plays of light and color.
Light was associated with divinity, but also with beauty and perfection in medieval times.

Medieval miniatures feature the use of gold, which generates areas of great light intensity.
Gold in medieval miniatures is often contrasted with cold and light tones to provide greater chromaticism.
In painting, light did not have the prominence it had in architecture during the medieval period.
Medieval "proper light" was alien to reality and without contact with the spectator.
Light in medieval painting neither came from outside nor expanded outward.
Shadows were forbidden in medieval painting as they were considered a refuge for evil.
Light was considered of divine origin and conqueror of darkness in the medieval period.
Light in medieval painting illuminated everything equally, resulting in the lack of modeling and volume in the objects.
The weightless and incorporeal image was sought to emphasize spirituality in medieval painting.
There is a greater interest in the representation of light in a symbolic manner in painting.
Gold backgrounds in painting developed a spatial staging, representing a metaphysical realm linked to the sacred.
"Gothic light" was a feigned illumination and created a type of unreal image that transcended mere nature.
The "unnatural" light of Gothic art is also presented as the bearer of a world of images of great figurative opulence.
The gold background reinforced the sacred symbolism of light in Gothic art.
The figures in Gothic art are immersed in an indeterminate space of unnatural light.
Cennino Cennini compiled various technical procedures for the use of gold leaf in painting.
Gold leaf was used profusely in halos and backgrounds in early Gothic painting.
A layer of red clay was spread before applying the gold leaf in early Gothic painting.
Incisions were made in the gilding to achieve more brilliance and to catch the light.
In early Gothic painting, there are no shadows, but the entire representation is uniformly illuminated.
Medieval painting suppresses the shadow, raising its sensitive light to the power of a super-sensitive light.
The Scrovegni Chapel in Padua features frescoes painted by Giotto.
Giotto studied how to distinguish flat and curved surfaces in his frescoes by using gradients.
Giotto distinguished the orientation of flat surfaces in his frescoes using three tones.
Lighter tones were used for horizontal surfaces, medium tones for frontal vertical surfaces, and darker tones for receding vertical surfaces.
Giotto was the first painter to represent sunlight in his frescoes.
Sunlight in Giotto's frescoes served to model figures and enhance the quality of clothes and objects.
Taddeo Gaddi painted the Annunciation to the Shepherds in the Baroncelli Chapel of Santa Croce in Florence.
Gaddi depicted divine light in a night scene with a visible light source in the Annunciation to the Shepherds.
The pattern of light distribution in Gaddi's painting is characteristic of point sources of light.
The pattern of light distribution in Gaddi's painting features contrasts of yellow and violet.
The brothers Hubert and Jan van Eyck and Robert Campin sought to capture various plays of light on surfaces of different textures and sheen in their paintings.
The Triptych of Mérode was painted by Robert Campin between 1425 and 1428.
The Polyptych of Ghent was painted by Hubert and Jan van Eyck in 1432.
Hubert van Eyck was the first to develop a certain sense of saturation of light in his Hours of Turin (1414-1417).
The Hours of Turin features the first "modern landscapes" of Western painting.
Hubert recreated effects such as the reflection of the evening sky on the water or the light sparkling on the waves of a lake in the Hours of Turin.

Linear perspective emerged as a new method of composition during the Renaissance.
Light became more naturalistic in Renaissance art due to an empirical study of physical reality.
Renaissance culture was influenced by classical Greco-Roman philosophy and a return to rationalism.
Theology took a back seat in the Renaissance, and the object of study of the philosopher returned to the human being, which is known as humanism.
The use of canvas as a support and the technique of oil painting became widespread in Venice from 1460.
Oil painting provided a greater chromatic richness and facilitated the representation of brightness and light effects.
In Renaissance painting, light tended to be intense in the foreground, diminishing progressively towards the background.
Light in Renaissance painting was often fixed, creating an aseptic space subordinated to the idealizing character of the painting.
Chiaroscuro was recovered as a method to give relief to objects during the Renaissance.
The study of gradation as a technique to diminish the intensity of color and modeling to graduate the different values of light and shadow was deepened during the Renaissance.
Natural light in Renaissance painting not only determined the space of the pictorial composition but also the volume of figures and objects.
Light lost its metaphorical character in Renaissance painting and became a tool for measuring and ordering reality.
Light had a special relevance in landscape painting during the Renaissance.
The first theoretical treatises on the representation of light in painting appeared during the Renaissance.
Leonardo da Vinci dedicated a good part of his Treatise on Painting to the scientific study of light.
Albrecht Dürer investigated a mathematical procedure to determine the location of shadows cast by objects illuminated by point source lights.
Giovanni Paolo Lomazzo devoted the fourth book of his Trattato (1584) to light.
Cennino Cennini took up in his treatise Il libro dell'arte the rule of Philoponus on the creation of distance by contrasts.

Alberti pointed out three fundamental concepts in painting: circumscriptio, compositio, and luminum receptio.
Alberti stated that color is a quality of light.
Alberti said that to color is to "give light" to a painting.
Alberti pointed out that relief in painting is achieved by the effects of light and shadow.
Alberti warned that the color is lighter where the rays of light fall.
Alberti said that the color becomes darker where the strength of the light gradually diminishes.
Alberti spoke of the use of white as the main tool for creating brilliance.
The painter has nothing but white pigment to imitate the flash of the most polished surfaces.
Alberti's theories greatly influenced Florentine painting in the mid-15th century.

The Baroque emerged in the 17th century as a more refined and ornamented style, characterized by the survival of a certain classicist rationalism, dynamic and dramatic forms, and a taste for the surprising and the anecdotal, optical illusions, and striking effects.
Baroque painting had a marked geographical differentiating accent, with various national schools, each with a distinctive stamp, but with a common influence coming from Italy.

In Italy, two opposing trends emerged during the Baroque: naturalism (also called Caravagism), based on the imitation of natural reality, with a certain taste for chiaroscuro (tenebrism), and classicism, which is just as realistic but with a more intellectual and idealized concept of reality.

In the so-called "full baroque" (second half of the 17th and early 18th centuries), painting evolved to a more decorative style, with a predominance of mural painting and a certain predilection for optical effects (trompe-l'œil) and luxurious and exuberant scenographies.
During the Baroque, many scientific studies on light were carried out, which influenced its pictorial representation.

In the background plane of the painting, a new light source is included.

L'Encyclopédie, the great project of Diderot and d'Alembert, differentiates between several types of shadows.
An "inherent" shadow is the object itself.
A "cast" shadow is that which is projected onto another surface.
A "projected" shadow results from the interposition of a solid between a surface and the light source.
"Tilted shading" is when the angle is on the vertical axis.
"Tilted shading" is also when it is on the horizontal axis.
Light sources are coded as "point", "ambient light" and "extensive".
A "point" light source produces shadows with clipped edges.
"Ambient light" produces no shadow.
An "extensive" light source produces shadows with little clipping divided into two areas: "umbra" and "penumbra".
"Umbra" is the darkened part of the area where the light source is located.
"Penumbra" is the darkened part of the edge of a single proportion of the light area.

John Constable was a prominent member of the field of landscape painting.

Constable believed that the form of an object is indifferent.
Constable believed that light, shadow, and perspective will always make an object beautiful.

In Germany, Caspar David Friedrich stands out as a painter with a pantheistic and poetic vision of nature.
Friedrich's uncorrupted and idealized nature features the human figure only as a spectator of nature's grandeur and infinity.
During his early years, Friedrich developed a style marked by sure contours and subtle play of light and shadow in watercolor, oil, or sepia ink.
One of Friedrich's first notable works is "The Cross on the Mountain" (1808, Gemäldegalerie Neue Meister, Dresden).

In "The Cross on the Mountain," a cross with Christ crucified stands on a pyramid of rocks against the light, in front of a sky furrowed with clouds and crossed by five beams of light emerging from an invisible sun.
The sun in "The Cross on the Mountain" is intuited to be behind the mountain, but it is unclear whether it is sunrise or sunset.
One of the beams in "The Cross on the Mountain" generates reflections on the crucifix, indicating it is a metal sculpture.
During his early years, Friedrich focused on landscapes and seascapes with warm sunrise and sunset lights.
He also experimented with the effects of winter, stormy, and foggy lights.
A more mature work by Friedrich is "Memorial Image for Johann Emanuel Bremer" (1817, Alte Nationalgalerie, Berlin).
"Memorial Image for Johann Emanuel Bremer" is a night scene with a strong symbolic content alluding to death.
In the foreground of "Memorial Image for Johann Emanuel Bremer," a garden appears in twilight, with rays of the moon filtering through a fence.
The background of "Memorial Image for Johann Emanuel Bremer" represents the afterlife with a faint light of dawn.
Johan Christian Dahl was a Norwegian painter who moved in the wake of Friedrich.

Philipp Otto Runge developed his own theory of color.

Realism succeeded Romanticism in the 19th century.

Impressionism is a style based on the representation of an image according to the "impression" that light produces to the eye.
Light plays a fundamental role in impressionism.
Impressionists sought to capture reality on the canvas as they perceived it visually.
Impressionists gave all the prominence to light and color.
Impressionists used to paint outdoors, capturing the various effects of light on the surrounding environment at different times of the day.
Impressionists studied in depth the laws of optics and the physics of light and color.
The technique of the Impressionists was based on loose brushstrokes and a combination of colors applied according to the viewer's vision.
There is a preponderance of contrast between elementary colors (yellow, red and blue) and their complements (orange, green and violet) in impressionism.
Impressionists used to apply the pigment directly on the canvas, without mixing.
This direct application of pigment resulted in greater luminosity and brilliance in impressionist paintings.
Impressionism perfected the capture of light by means of fragmented touches of color.
Artists such as Giorgione, Titian, Guardi and Velázquez had used this procedure of fragmented touches of color to a greater or lesser extent before the impressionists.
The Impressionists admired the genius of Las Meninas, whom they considered "the painter of painters".
For the Impressionists, light was the protagonist of the painting.
Impressionists began to paint from life, capturing at all times the variations of light on landscapes and objects.

Impressionists abandoned chiaroscuro and violent contrasts of light and shadow.

The Impressionist painters often depicted scenes in bars, cafés, dances, theaters, and other establishments.

Several styles derived from Impressionism emerged, such as Neo-Impressionism.

Neo-Impressionism is also called Divisionism or Pointillism.
Pointillism is a technique in which there is no precise source of illumination.
Each point is a light source in itself in Pointillism.
The composition is based on juxtaposed ("divided") dots of a pure color.
These dots merge in the eye of the viewer at a given distance.
When these juxtaposed colors are complementary (red-green, yellow-violet, orange-blue), a greater luminosity is achieved.
Pointillism defends the exclusive use of pure and complementary colors.
These colors are applied in small brushstrokes in the form of dots.
These dots compose the image on the viewer's retina at a certain distance.
Georges Seurat and Paul Signac were the best exponents of Pointillism.

Symbolism is a main characteristic of art that values aesthetics, and it is a reaction to the prevailing utilitarianism of the time and to the ugliness and materialism of the industrial era.
Symbolism gives art and beauty an autonomy of their own, which is synthesized in Théophile Gautier's formula "art for art's sake" (L'art pour l'art).
Symbolism is linked to modernism, also known as Art Nouveau in France, Modern Style in the United Kingdom, Jugendstil in Germany, Sezession in Austria, or Liberty in Italy.
Symbolism is an anti-scientific and anti-naturalist movement.

Light, in symbolism, loses objectivity and is used as a symbolic element, suggesting spirituality, whether religious or pantheistic, or perhaps simply a state of mind of the artist, a feeling, an emotion.
Light, by its dematerialization, exerts a powerful influence on symbolist artists.
The conception of light in symbolism is often far removed from the physical world, although for its execution, impressionist and pointillist techniques are often used.
Symbolism originated in France.
Gustave Moreau is a French figure who was trained in romanticism under the influence of his teacher, Théodore Chassériau.

Moreau evolved a personal style in both subject matter and technique, with mystical images with a strong component of sensuality, a resplendent chromaticism with an enamel-like finish, and the use of a chiaroscuro of golden shadows.
Odilon Redon is a French figure who developed a fantastic and dreamlike theme, influenced by the literature of Edgar Allan Poe.
Until the age of fifty, Redon worked almost exclusively in charcoal drawing and lithography.
Redon later became an excellent colorist, both in oil and pastel.
Pierre Puvis de Chavannes is a French figure who is an outstanding muralist.
Puvis de Chavannes's preference for cold tones gives his work the appearance of fresco painting.

Arnold Böcklin specialized in painting fantastic beings with a somber and morbid style.
Böcklin's painting "The Island of the Dead" (1880, Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York) features Charon's boat and a pale, cold, and whitish light.
Ferdinand Hodler evolved from naturalism to a personal style he called "parallelism."
Hodler's "parallelism" is characterized by rhythmic schemes with line, form, and color reproduced in a repetitive way.
Hodler's simplified and monumental figures often show great luminosity in landscapes.
Gustav Klimt had academic training and developed a personal style synthesizing impressionism, modernism, and symbolism.
Klimt preferred mural painting with allegorical themes, often with erotic tendencies.
Klimt's decorative style includes arabesques, butterfly wings, and peacocks, with a golden color providing intense luminosity.
Giuseppe Pellizza da Volpedo was formed in the divisionist environment and evolved to a personal style with intense and vibrant light.
Pellizza da Volpedo's "Lost Hopes" (1894, Ponti-Grün collection, Rome) is an example of his early divisionist work.
In "The Rising Sun or the Sun" (1903-1904, National Gallery of Modern Art, Rome), Pellizza da Volpedo created a prodigious exercise in light exaltation.
The symbolic reading of "The Rising Sun or the Sun" may represent the new society aspired to by socialism.
Christian Krohg was a Norwegian painter known for combining natural and artificial lights with theatrical effects and unreal connotations.
Krohg's "The Sleeping Seamstress" (1885, Nasjonalgalleriet, Oslo) features a double presence of a lamp and daylight, creating a sense of timelessness.
Vilhelm Hammershøi was a Danish painter who was a virtuoso in handling light, considering it the main protagonist
Avant-garde movements arose that sought to integrate art into society through a greater interrelation between the artist and the spectator.
The spectator interprets the work and can discover meanings that the artist did not even know.
Avant-gardism rejected traditional methods of optical representation, such as Renaissance perspective.
Avant-gardism vindicated the two-dimensionality of painting and the autonomous character of the image.
This implied the abandonment of space and light contrasts.
In place of light and shadow, they became integral parts of the image.
Photography, film, and video had a notable influence on the art of the century.
The new interrelationship with the spectator means that the artist does not reflect what he sees.
Instead, the spectator sees the artist's vision of reality.
Each person interprets this vision individually.
Advances in artificial light led society to a new sensitivity to luminous impacts.
Artists reflected on the technical and aesthetic properties of new technological advances.
Many artists experimented with all kinds of lights and their interrelation.
This included the mixture and interweaving of natural and artificial lights.
The control of the focal point, the dense atmospheres, the shaded or transparent colors, and other types of sensorial experiences were also explored.
The emergence of the avant-garde at the turn of the century brought a rapid succession of artistic movements.
Each movement had a particular technique and a particular vision of the function of light and color in painting.
Fauvism (1904-1908) was one of the first movements of the 20th century concerned with light and color.
Fauvism involved experimentation in the field of color.
Colors were conceived in a subjective and personal way.
Emotional and expressive values were applied to color, independent of nature.
For these artists, colors had to generate emotions.
A new conception of pictorial illumination arose, which consisted in the negation of shadows.

Expressionism is a diverse movement with multiple tendencies and a variety of influences.
Precedents for expressionism can be found in the works of Edvard Munch and James Ensor.
Expressionist light is more conceptual than sensorial.
Expressionist light expresses the artist's mentality, consciousness, and way of seeing the world.
Die Brücke is a group of expressionist artists that includes Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Erich Heckel, Karl Schmidt-Rottluff, and Emil Nolde.
The Vienna Group is a group of expressionist artists that includes Egon Schiele and Oskar Kokoschka.
The School of Paris is a group of expressionist artists that includes Amedeo Modigliani, Marc Chagall, Georges Rouault, and Chaïm Soutine.
Edvard Munch is an expressionist artist who is linked to symbolism.
Munch's early work reflects a certain existential anguish.
Munch's personal painting has a strong psychological introspection.
In Munch's work, light is a reflection of the emptiness of existence.
The members of Die Brücke developed a dark, introspective, and anguished subject matter.
The members of Die Brücke include Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Erich Heckel, and Karl Schmidt-Rottluff.
The light in Die Brücke's works is not illuminating and does not respond to physical criteria.
Der Blaue Reiter is a group of expressionist artists that emerged in Munich in 1911.
Der Blaue Reiter includes Vasili Kandinski, Franz Marc, August Macke, and Paul Klee.
Der Blaue Reiter had a certain vision of art that prioritized the creative freedom and personal and subjective expression of the artist.
Der Blaue Reiter had a technical predilection for watercolor.

Cubism destroys the spatial perspective of Renaissance origin.

Pablo Picasso, a painter, went through the so-called blue and rose periods.
During the blue period, Picasso's paintings were influenced by El Greco.
In the blue period, Picasso painted elongated figures of dramatic appearance.
The elongated figures in Picasso's blue period paintings had profiles highlighted by a yellowish or greenish light and shadows of thick black brushstrokes.
During the rose period, Picasso dealt with kinder and more human themes.
The rose period paintings are characterized by scenes of figures immersed in empty landscapes of luminous appearance.
Picasso's cubist stage is divided into two phases: analytical cubism and synthetic cubism.
In analytical cubism, Picasso focused on portraits and still lifes.
In analytical cubism, images were broken down into planes in which light lost its modeling and volume-defining character.
In analytical cubism, light became a constructive element that emphasized contrast, giving the image an iridescent appearance.
In synthetic cubism, Picasso expanded the chromatic range and included extra-pictorial elements.
Extra-pictorial elements in synthetic cubism included texts and fragments of literary works.
Picasso's most famous work is Guernica, which is entirely elaborated in shades of gray.
Guernica is a night scene illuminated by the lights of a light bulb in the ceiling.
The light bulb in Guernica is shaped like a sun and an eye at the same time.
In Guernica, there is a character leaning out of the window holding a quinque, which provides light.
The light in Guernica is constructed by planes that serve as counterpoints of light in the midst of darkness.
Orphism is a movement derived from Cubism.
Robert Delaunay is a representative of Orphism.
Delaunay experimented with light and color in his abstracting search for rhythm and movement.
Delaunay's series on the Eiffel Tower and Field of Mars are examples of his Orphic paintings
La jornada del operario is a painting created by Gino Severini in 1904.
The painting is in a private collection.
The work is divided into three scenes.
The scenes are separated by frames.
Two scenes are on the left and one scene is on the right.
The scene on the right is of double size.
The scenes represent dawn, noon, and twilight.
The painting depicts various phases of the construction of a building.
The two scenes on the left are actually a single image separated by a frame.
The single image has a different treatment of light for the time of day.
Arc Lamp is a painting created by Gino Severini between 1911 and 1912.
The painting is in the Museum of Modern Art in New York.
The painting is an analytical study of the patterns and colors of a beam of light.
The beam of light is an artificial light in conflict with moonlight.
The painting contains symbolism.
The electric light represents the energy of youth.
The lunar light represents classicism and romanticism.
The light seems to be observed under a microscope.
From the incandescent center of the lamp, a series of colored arrows sprouts.
The colored arrows gradually lose chromatism as they move away from the bright focus.
The colored arrows merge with the darkness.
Gino Severini stated that the splendor of light is obtained by bringing pure colors closer together.
The painting is not only original as a work of art, but also scientific.
Gino Severini sought to represent light by separating the colors that compose it.
Futurism is a movement that influenced various parallel movements outside Italy.
English Vorticism is one of the movements influenced by Futurism.
Christopher Richard Wynne Nevinson is the best exponent of English Vorticism.
Starry Shell is a painting created by Christopher Richard Wynne Nevinson in 1916.

The path towards abstraction in art can be traced back to two main sources: a psychic-emotive path originating from symbolism and expressionism, and an objective-optical path derived from fauvism and cubism.
In the objective-optical path, light plays a significant role. Starting from the cubist light beams, artists began to isolate light and express it in abstract forms, moving away from natural reality.
In abstract art, light loses its prominence but is still perceived through various tonal gradations and chiaroscuro games.
Mark Rothko, an abstract artist, is known for his images of intense chromaticism that have a luminosity that seems to radiate from the color itself.

Vasili Kandinski, a pioneer of abstraction, was inspired to create abstract works when he saw one of his paintings with sunlight shining brightly, diluting the forms and accentuating the chromaticism.
Kandinski's research into abstract art continued with Russian suprematism, especially with Kazimir Malevich, an artist with post-impressionist and fauvist roots who later adopted cubism.
Malevich's geometric abstraction in works such as "Black on Black" (1913) and "White on White" (1919) gives special relevance to color.
In the interwar period, the New Objectivity (Neue Sachlichkeit) movement emerged in Germany, which returned to realistic figuration and objective representation of the surrounding reality.
The New Objectivity movement had a marked social and vindictive component and did not renounce the technical and aesthetic achievements of avant-garde art.
The urban landscape, populated with artificial lights, played a special role in the New Objectivity movement.
Otto Dix, George Grosz, and Max Beckmann were main representatives of the New Objectivity movement.
Surrealism (1924-1955) placed special emphasis on imagination, fantasy, and the world of dreams, with a strong influence of psychoanalysis.
Surrealist painting moved between figuration and abstraction.
René Magritte, a surrealist painter, treated light
The light in Empordà, a region in Spain, is described as "static, clear, shining, sharp, glittering" by Josep Pla.
Salvador Dalí's treatment of light is generally surprising and includes singular fantastic effects, contrasts of light and shadow, backlighting and countershadows.
Dalí continuously researched new and surprising effects in his paintings.
In 1948, Dalí abandoned avant-gardism and returned to classicist painting, interpreting it in a personal and subjective way.
Dalí's "atomic stage" involved seeking to capture reality through the principles of quantum physics.
Among Dalí's last works are "Christ of Saint John of the Cross", "The Last Supper", "The Perpignan Station", and "Cosmic Athlete".
Joan Miró's works reflect a light of magical and telluric aspect.
Miró's light is rooted in the landscape of the countryside of Tarragona.
La masía, a work by Miró, is illuminated by a twilight that bathes objects in contrast with the incipient darkness of the sky.
Miró uses flat and dense colors in preferably nocturnal environments.
Objects and figures in Miró's works seem bathed in an unreal light.
Miró felt a special devotion for the light of stars.
In the United States, between the 1920s and 1930s, several figurative movements emerged.
The Ashcan School was the first of these movements.
Robert Henri was the leader of the Ashcan School.
George Wesley Bellows and John French Sloan were notable artists in the Ashcan School.
The Ashcan School developed a style of cold tones and dark palette.
The Ashcan School's theme was centered on marginalization and the world of nightlife.
American realism or American Scene was a movement that followed the Ashcan School.
Edward Hopper was the main representative of American realism or American Scene.

The critic described the light in Hopper's mysterious paintings as a light that "illuminates but never warms."
The critic saw the light as being at the service of Hopper's vision of the desolate American urban landscape.
After the Second World War, art underwent a rapid evolution with styles and movements following each other more and more rapidly.
The modern project originated with the historical avant-gardes.
This project reached its culmination with various anti-material styles that emphasized the intellectual origin of art over its material realization.
Examples of these anti-material styles include action art and conceptual art.
After the culmination of the modern project, there was a return to classical forms of art.
This return accepted the material and aesthetic component of art.
It also renounced art's revolutionary and society-transforming character.
This return marked the emergence of postmodern art.
In postmodern art, artists shamelessly transit between different techniques and styles.
This transit lacks a vindictive character.
Postmodern artists return to artisanal work as the essence of the artist.
The first movements after the war were abstract.
Examples of these abstract movements include American abstract expressionism and European informalism.
These movements occurred from 1945 to 1960.
Abstract expressionism is also called action painting.
Abstract expressionism is characterized by the use of the dripping technique.
In this technique, paint is dripped onto the canvas.
The artist then intervenes on the canvas with various tools or with their own body.
Notable members of the abstract expressionist movement include Jackson Pollock and Mark Rothko.
Pollock used pigments, glitter, and aluminum enamel in his works.
The aluminum enamel stands out for its brightness.
This gives Pollock's works a metallic light and creates a kind of chiaroscuro.
Rothko worked in oil with overlapping layers of very fluid paint.

The Cappella series was created by Soto in 1964 and focused on the opposition between light and dark combined with shapes.
Soto's Vega series was created in 1967 and was made with aluminum paint and gold and silver glitter, which caused the light to reverberate.
Soto's serial painting was influenced by dodecaphonism and featured primary colors that stood out for their transparency and provoked a strong sensation of movement.
Agam was particularly interested in chromatic combinations and worked with 150 different colors in painting or sculpture-painting.
Pop art emerged in the United States in 1955 as a movement to reject abstract expressionism.
Pop art includes a series of authors who returned to figuration with a marked component of popular inspiration.
Images in pop art were inspired by the world of advertising, photography, comics, and mass media.
Roy Lichtenstein stood out in pop art and was particularly inspired by comics.
Lichtenstein's paintings look like vignettes and sometimes have the typical graininess of printed comics.
Lichtenstein used flat inks, without mixtures, in pure colors.
Lichtenstein also produced landscapes with light colors and great luminosity.
Tom Wesselmann specialized in nudes, generally in bathrooms, with a cold and aseptic appearance.
Wesselmann used pure colors, without tonal gradations, with sharp contrasts.
James Rosenquist had a more surrealist vein and a preference for consumerist and advertising themes.
Andy Warhol was the most mediatic and commercial artist of this group.
Warhol used to work in silkscreen, in series ranging from portraits of famous people to all kinds of objects.
Warhol's colorism was garish and strident, and his technique was pure and impersonal.

Antonio López García is a Spaniard who is an author of academic works.
The artwork of Antonio López García combines a meticulous description of reality with a vague unreal aspect that is close to magical realism.
Antonio López García has created urban landscapes with wide atmospheres, such as "Madrid sur" (1965-1985) and "Madrid desde Torres Blancas" (1976-1982).
Antonio López García has also created images with an almost photographic aspect, such as "Mujer en la bañera" (1968).
In "Mujer en la bañera" (1968), a woman is taking a bath in an atmosphere of electric light that is reflected on the bathroom tiles.
This results in an intense and vibrant composition in "Mujer en la bañera" (1968).
Neo-luminism is an American art movement that is inspired by American luminism and the Hudson River School.
Neo-luminism emerged in opposition to modern art.
Neo-luminism is a socio-cultural theory that postulates the current validity of a historical period that would have surpassed the modern project.
The modern project is characterized culturally by the Enlightenment, politically by the French Revolution, and economically by the Industrial Revolution.
Neo-luminism adopted majestic skies and calm water marinas from American luminism and the Hudson River School.
Neo-luminism also adopted atmospheric effects of light rendered in subtle gradations from American luminism and the Hudson River School.
The main representatives of neo-luminism are James Doolin, April Gornik, Norman Lundin, Scott Cameron, Steven DaLuz, and Pauline Ziegen.
Postmodern art has predominated in the international art scene since 1975.
Postmodern art emerged in opposition to modern art.
Postmodern art is the art of postmodernity.
